title: Au Niger, le haoussa remplace le fran√ßais comme langue officielle dans une d√©marche de souverainet√© affirm√©e ¬∑ Global Voices en Fran√ßais
text:
Au Niger, le fran√ßais, impos√© pendant la p√©riode coloniale perd en mars 2025 son statut de langue officielle au profit de la langue haoussa. Cette d√©cision n'est pas tr√®s appr√©ci√©e dans la soci√©t√© nig√©rienne dans un contexte de tensions diplomatiques avec la France.
Le 17 mars 2025, la R√©publique du Niger et le Burkina Faso annoncent leur retrait de l‚ÄôOrganisation Internationale de la Francophonie (OIF). Au lendemain de cette annonce, le 18 mars 2025, le Mali embo√Æte le pas des deux autres pays. Le Niger et le Mali √©tant des membres fondateurs.) de l'organisation, la sortie de ces trois pays au total qui forment par ailleurs l‚ÄôAlliance des √âtats du Sahel portent ainsi un autre coup √† cette institution internationale √† laquelle ils appartiennent.
Sur le r√©seau X, le Conseil National pour la Sauvegarde de la Patrie du Niger (organe de gestion des institutions depuis le coup d‚Äô√âtat du 26 juillet 2023), publie sur son compte :
üî¥Retrait du Niger de l'Organisation Internationale de la Francophonie
[pic.twitter.com/yrX9vAeN0Y]‚Äî Conseil National pour la Sauvegarde de la Patrie (@NIGER_CNSP)
[March 17, 2025]
Quelques jours apr√®s cette annonce, les autorit√©s militaires nig√©riennes prennent une autre d√©cision pour rompre les liens avec la France: la r√©trogradation de la langue fran√ßaise au rang de langue de travail. D√©sormais, le haoussa est √©rig√© en langue officielle. Dans le pays, le fran√ßais est parl√© par 13% de la population.
Rupture avec l'h√©ritage colonial
Alors que onze langues locales ont le statut de langues nationales dans le pays, la langue haoussa est parl√©e par 47% des Nig√©riens, presque la moiti√© d'une population de plus de 27 millions d'habitants. Cette r√©alit√© justifie la promotion de cette langue au rang de langue officielle selon Isma√´l, jeune √©tudiant √† l‚ÄôUniversit√© Abdou Moumouni de Niamey, capitale du pays. Interview√© par Global Voices sur Whatsapp, il explique:
Je ne peux pas remettre en question cette d√©cision des autorit√©s. Nous avons plusieurs langues parl√©es dans notre pays mais elles ont juste le statut de langues nationales, alors qu'elles enregistrent plus de locuteurs que le fran√ßais. D'ailleurs cette langue coloniale n'est parl√©e que par moins de 15% des Nig√©riens. C'est une reconnaissance √† la langue haoussa qui est parl√©e et comprise par beaucoup de personnes dans le pays.
Pour Ibrahima Amadou [nom d'emprunt], √©galement interview√©e sur WhatsApp, cette d√©cision rentre dans le prolongement de l'affirmation souveraine des nouveaux dirigeants du pays. Pour elle, ces derniers se sont engag√©s dans un processus de souverainet√© totale du pays, et prennent donc des d√©cisions pour justifier leurs d√©marches.
Le concept de souverainet√© doit √™tre assum√© sur tous les plans. Ils ne peuvent pas d√©noncer des pratiques coloniales et garder le fran√ßais, une langue coloniale qui nous a √©t√© impos√©e, comme langue nationale. Donner √† la langue
[haoussa]le statut de langue officielle est justifi√©.
Sur le r√©seau X, un compte au nom African Stream salue et soutient cette d√©cision du Niger:
NIGER SAYS ‚ÄòGOODBYE FRENCH,
HELLO HAUSA!‚ÄôNiger has broken free from another colonial chain ‚Äì the French language ‚Äì by adopting Hausa as the country‚Äôs new national idiom. Hausa is indigenous to, and widely spoken in, West Africa. Along with fellow Alliance of Sahel States. members Burkina Faso and Mali, Niger also recently ditched the body representing La Francophonie ‚Äì i.e., the ‚ÄòFrench speaking‚Äô world (or rather, those parts of the world that had French imposed on them by colonial France). Hausa is one of the most commonly spoken African languages. More Nigerians speak Hausa than French. In 2012, only 20% of Nigerians were literate in French. Switching to Hausa is a powerful affirmation of African heritage, identity and sovereignty.
[pic.twitter.com/hHCiZipnOk]‚Äî African Stream (@african_stream)
[April 10, 2025]
LE NIGER DIT ¬´ AU REVOIR LE FRAN√áAIS ¬ª, BONJOUR LE HAOUSSA ! Le Niger s'est lib√©r√© d'une autre cha√Æne coloniale ‚Äì la langue fran√ßaise ‚Äì en adoptant le haoussa comme nouvel idiome national. Le haoussa est une langue indig√®ne et largement parl√©e en Afrique de l'Ouest. √Ä l'instar du Burkina Faso et du Mali, membres de l'Alliance des √âtats du Sahel, le Niger a r√©cemment abandonn√© l'organisation repr√©sentant la Francophonie ‚Äì c'est-√†-dire le monde francophone (ou plut√¥t, les r√©gions du monde qui se sont vues imposer le fran√ßais par la France coloniale). Le haoussa est l'une des langues africaines les plus parl√©es. Les Nig√©rians sont plus nombreux √† parler le haoussa que le fran√ßais. En 2012, seulement 20 % des Nig√©rians savaient lire et √©crire en fran√ßais. Passer au haoussa est une puissante affirmation de l'h√©ritage, de l'identit√© et de la souverainet√© africaines.
‚Äî African Stream (@african_stream)
[April 10, 2025]
Un coup dur pour l'√©ducation
Dans le syst√®me √©ducatif au Niger, le fran√ßais a toujours √©t√© la langue d'enseignement principale, bien que l'enseignement en langues nationales est encourag√© depuis le bas √¢ge.
En 2018, en raison de l'abandon croissant des √©tudes par une grande majorit√© des enfants et jeunes, le gouvernement avait opt√© pour un renforcent des enseignements en langues locales, comme l'indique cet article du journal [LeMonde](https://www.lemonde.fr/afrique/article/2018/02/02/face-a-la-descolarisation-le-niger-mise-sur-l-enseignement-en-langues-locales_5250931_3212.html). Interview√©e en f√©vrier 2018, Rabiou Rachida, enseignante contractuelle de la classe de CIB (premi√®re ann√©e de l‚Äô√©cole √©l√©mentaire), affirmait au journal LeMonde :
En
[zarma][deuxi√®me langue la plus parl√©e au Niger avec plus 18% de locuteurs], les enfants comprennent plus facilement et plus vite qu‚Äôen fran√ßais.
Cette d√©claration de l'enseignante confirme l'importance d'une √©ducation en langues locales, argument repris par les autorit√©s militaires au pouvoir aujourd'hui au Niger.
Mais Affiz Ousmane, √©tudiant √† l‚Äô[Universit√© Dan Dicko Dankoulodo de Maradi](https://www.uddm.edu.ne/) (UDDM) situ√©e dans la ville de [Maradi](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maradi) (au centre du pays) interview√© par Global Voices, estime que le changement aussi rapide du statut de la langue fran√ßaise risque affecter n√©gativement le syst√®me √©ducatif:
Le changement est brusque, brutal et c'est l'√©ducation qui va prendre un coup. Notre syst√®me √©ducatif a toujours √©t√© en langue fran√ßaise, surtout le niveau sup√©rieur. Il va falloir r√©organiser cela en profondeur pour ne pas faire de victimes.
J'esp√®re vivement que ce changement ne se fera pas de la fa√ßon dont les autorit√©s militaires ont rompu les relations avec la France et les institutions internationales auxquelles nous appartenons.
Depuis le coup d‚Äô√âtat du 26 juillet 2023, il est clair que la d√©t√©rioration des relations entre le Niger et la France donne lieu √† une profonde transformation de la soci√©t√© nig√©rienne. D√©j√† en octobre 2024, les autorit√©s militaires ont proc√©d√© au [retrait des noms fran√ßais](https://www.lemonde.fr/afrique/article/2024/10/16/niger-a-niamey-la-junte-debaptise-des-rues-et-monuments-aux-noms-francais_6353349_3212.html) dans les espaces publics en [rebaptisant des avenues, monuments](https://www.lemonde.fr/afrique/article/2024/10/16/niger-a-niamey-la-junte-debaptise-des-rues-et-monuments-aux-noms-francais_6353349_3212.html) et autres lieux avec des noms de personnes et devenant purement nig√©riens.

title: Sibanye-Stillwater plans to lay off 700 Montana mining workers
text:
By Blair Miller ,
5 hours ago The entrance to the East Boulder mine owned by Sibanye-Stillwater in the Custer-Gallatin National Forest, about 25 miles from Big Timber (Photo by Darrell Ehrlick of the Daily Montanan).
The Sibanye-Stillwater mining company announced Thursday it plans to lay off around 700 employees in Montana as part of a restructuring due in part to a dive in palladium prices and the loss of more than $350 million in Montana since the start of 2023.
The layoff announcement comes less than a year after the company announced it was laying off around 100 employees in Montana. The company owns the Stillwater and East Boulder operations , which are southwest of Columbus, as well as the Columbus Metallurgical Complex.
The company is the largest employer in Stillwater County and employs people from across south-central and southeastern Montana, said Sen. Forrest Mandeville, R-Columbus. The layoff announcement led to both of Montana‚Äôs U.S. senators introducing a bill within hours seeking to ban the import of Russian palladium that the company says has caused massive losses.
In a letter sent to employees Tuesday following a corporate results call for the first half of the year , in which the company‚Äôs CEO announced Sibanye-Stillwater was cutting about 800 jobs as part of the restructuring. Kevin Robertson, the company‚Äôs U.S. platinum group metals operations executive vice president, said the layoffs will start Nov. 12, but salaried employees who will lose their jobs will be notified by email on Thursday and hourly employees will be contacted by their union.
The DLI said 700 jobs would account for about 13% of all payroll jobs in Stillwater and Sweet Grass counties, about 20% of those counties‚Äô total wages, and about 16% of all statewide mining jobs.
A spokesperson for the company said he did not have exact figures, but the average annual salary was around $110,000 and a ‚Äúsignificant‚Äù benefits package.
‚ÄúWe estimate that this restructure will reduce our total number of employees at our Montana operations from approximately 1,680 on July 31 to just under 1,000 after layoffs,‚Äù Robertson said in the letter. ‚ÄúWe know this will be a very difficult time for everyone and want to ensure employees receive the support they need.‚Äù
The Montana operations produce about 78% palladium and 22% platinum, according to the company. But it says palladium prices have fallen from $2,305 per ounce two years ago, to $1,280 per ounce last summer, and now to below $1,000 per ounce. Palladium futures opened the day trading at $1,015 per ounce and had jumped to $1,057 per ounce as of 2 p.m. MT.
Earth movers and bulldozers work at preparing a site on the East Boulder and Custer-Gallatin National Forest. The site will eventually become a tailings storage facility for Sibayne-Stillwater mining (Photo by Darrell Ehrlick of the Daily Montanan). The company says it believes Russia is inundating the palladium market to tank its prices, and prices for imported palladium in the U.S. have dropped by almost 40% this year.
The company said it had increased production by 8% the first half of this year compared to the latter half of last year, but costs have outpaced sale prices, resulting in the Montana operations losing $265 million last year and $87 million in the first half of 2024.
‚ÄúThis responsible and sustainable mining and metals processing is much, much more expensive than that of our competitors in Russia and other areas,‚Äù Robertson said in the letter. ‚ÄúTo compete with those low-cost operations, we need to solidify government and other stakeholder support in the long-term. In the short-term, we have no choice but to reduce our losses as we continue to lobby for additional forms of financial support.‚Äù
The western section of the Stillwater mine started producing in 1986 and the eastern section is in a buildup phase. The East Boulder mine has been in production since 2002.
Robertson‚Äôs letter said the company planned to pause operations at Stillwater West and continue production at Stillwater East and East Boulder, with the hopes of resuming operations at Stillwater West ‚Äúas prices permit.‚Äù It also plans to use four ramps instead of six at East Boulder and to reduce operations at the Metallurgical Complex while recycling continues.
The company said each site and department is finalizing restructuring plans up through Nov. 12, when the initial layoffs will occur. Employees could be eligible for severance and will be eligible for benefits through November, Robertson‚Äôs letter said.
The letter also said it plans to ask other local employers who are hiring to ‚Äúhelp place as many laid-off employees as possible into other jobs.‚Äù
The letter says the company hopes to bring Stillwater West back online as soon as possible, that it is committed to the local community, and that it is optimistic the market will recover and government will support the mineral mining efforts.
‚ÄúThe decision to pause operations at Stillwater West and to curtail production at East Boulder was one we put considerable thought, time, and effort into and delayed as long as we could,‚Äù Robertson wrote in the letter. ‚ÄúBut to continue to operate at these losses would jeopardize our ability to operate at all. We are therefore now undertaking this significant restructuring that we believe will ultimately result in a sustainable business.‚Äù
The letter said the company planned to meet with United Steelworkers leadership ‚Äúwith the hope of working together to ensure the long-term sustainability of our operations and our employment opportunities.‚Äù
United Steelworkers is under the umbrella of the AFL-CIO in Montana. AFL-CIO executive secretary Jason Small said the ‚Äúvast majority‚Äù of employees at the company‚Äôs Montana sites are union workers, but he was unsure Thursday afternoon exactly how many union members would lose their jobs.
Small said he suspects some of the laid off employees will try to find similar underground mining work in other states like Nevada, New Mexico and Arizona because it would be difficult to immediately find jobs in south-central Montana. But he said he believes some will stay in state.
‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a possibility that some people can become boilermakers, some can become laborers, pipe-fitters, ironworkers,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúYou know, there‚Äôs some opportunity there if they‚Äôre trying to stay in state.‚Äù
He said he had already spoken with the Department of Labor and Industry, which will be putting out active response teams to help coordinate job help and training for the affected workers.
‚ÄúWe‚Äôre more than willing to step in and do that again. They‚Äôll have a team set up and ready to roll to help get these guys going,‚Äù Small said. ‚Äú‚Ä¶We‚Äôre in support of the workers, and we‚Äôre going to do everything we can in conjunction with whatever partners we need, whether it be DLI or any others, to help get these guys transitioned and keep them moving and prosperous.‚Äù
Department of Labor and Industry Commissioner Sarah Swanson said in a statement that DLI will in coming days release a mining-specific skills matching tool to help workers find new job opportunities using the skills they have.
‚ÄúUsing this tool combined with the exemplary work of our job service workforce consultants, we will help affected workers navigate employment opportunities, identify any skill gaps needed to advance into new careers, and source funding for any necessary training programs needed to acquire additional skills,‚Äù she said in a statement.
Montana officials call layoffs ‚Äòunacceptable,‚Äô ‚Äòsignificant blow‚Äô
Montana Gov. Greg Gianforte called the layoffs ‚Äúa significant blow‚Äù to the workers and community and said the state would bring ‚Äúevery available resource‚Äù forward to help the affected families.
‚ÄúThis is a challenging time for the mining sector. The ongoing regulatory assault on mining and natural resources has burdened this critical sector of our economy,‚Äù Gianforte said in a statement. ‚ÄúThe fact is the United States cannot and should not have to rely on our foreign adversaries for energy, critical metals, or other resources. The United States must support these industries, and their workers, with a policy dedicated to making our nation energy and resource dominant and independent.‚Äù
The current tailings storage facility for Sibanye-Stillwater Mining in East Boulder, Montana. (Photo by Darrell Ehrlick of the Daily Montanan) U.S. Sens. Jon Tester (D) and Steve Daines (R) separately introduced similar bills Thursday in response to the layoff announcement that seek to prohibit the importation of critical minerals from Russia.
Tester‚Äôs office said he spoke with Deputy Treasury Secretary Wally Adeyamo after the announcement pushing the administration to help the laid off workers. He called it ‚Äúunacceptable‚Äù that Montanans were losing their jobs because of Russian critical mineral imports.
‚ÄúWhen I heard that Sibanye-Stillwater was laying off hundreds of hardworking Montana miners because of this Russian activity, I reached out to local officials and the workforce to team up and immediately introduce our bill to ban the importation of Russian palladium,‚Äù Tester said in a statement. ‚ÄúThis has gone on for far too long, and I will continue to stand with the Montanans who are being targeted by this unfair trade practice.‚Äù
Daines blamed the Biden-Harris administration for ‚Äúallowing‚Äù the imports to occur.
‚ÄúThere is no reason the United States should be importing critical minerals that we can find right here at home,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúMontana is rich in minerals, and we need to be supporting American mines and American jobs, not Russia‚Äôs.‚Äù
Mandeville, who is in Helena attending interim committee hearings this week, told the Daily Montanan he contacted county commissioners and DLI Commissioner Swanson shortly after learning about the layoffs Thursday to check what resources the state can bring to help affected workers and families in the region.
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs certainly a big deal to the area. I mean, the 700-800 families that are going to be affected by this are absolutely the first priority. And thinking about how they‚Äôre going to be able to deal with this fallout and the impacts just on the community that we‚Äôre going to see ‚Äì these are good people that are involved in a lot of stuff,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs going to be an impact on schools, on nonprofits, on churches ‚Äì everything that these individuals are involved in is definitely going to feel this.‚Äù
He said he worries how several hundred people losing their jobs might affect the community even if they can be placed into other jobs and that he had put Swanson in touch with Stillwater County officials and its economic development coordinator to ‚Äúmake sure we‚Äôre all playing on the same team.‚Äù
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs really going to be specific, family-to-family, individual-to-individual, on what help is needed,‚Äù Mandeville said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm confident that Commissioner Swanson is going to do what she can in her powers to make sure there‚Äôs resources available. And like I told her, I‚Äôll do what I can on my end to make sure people are familiar with those resources that come.‚Äù
‚ÄúOur team will host multiple in-person, onsite rapid response and career fair events in Columbus in the coming weeks and will be onsite when layoffs begin to ensure the Sibanye-Stillwater workers have the tools needed to identify new training and employment opportunities and to navigate Montana‚Äôs unemployment insurance system,‚Äù Commissioner Swanson said in a statement.
Editor‚Äôs note: This story has been updated to include information and comments from the DLI and the average salary of workers at the Montana sites.

title: West Valley Medical Center unveils $3 million upgrades
text:
CALDWELL, Idaho ‚Äî "We're really excited about the future that the hospital has," said Nicholas Manning, Chief Executive Officer of West Valley Medical Center.
Visitors will notice new upgrades as soon as they enter the main lobby or emergency room at West Valley Medical Center, which is celebrating its 75th anniversary this year.
"We really believe it was important for our hospital; we're celebrating our 75th anniversary this year, and so our building has been here for 75 years," said Isabella Chisholm, Chief Operating Officer.
Upgrades are also now complete in surgery spaces, the behavioral health unit, and the orthopedic and spine floor.
"We've added multiple orthopedic robots, spine robots, as well as a general robot for general needs. That has happened over the years, but just in the last year, we added orthopedic robots," Chisholm said.
Manning highlighted the importance of responding to community growth. "We've really assessed what is happening in terms of growth in this community and how we can best respond to that growth. We are assessing the service lines we need to support the community and which physicians and providers we need to support those service lines," he said.
The $3 million project, funded by the Health Care Company (HCA), has been a blessing for the beloved hospital, according to Manning.
"You know, we do a lot of amazing things here, from ensuring we run our trauma program successfully to being quick, attentive, and responsive from a stroke perspective and from a cardiology perspective," Manning said.
As the hospital celebrates its renovated areas, healthcare leaders say this is just the start.
"We are really expanding our services in behavioral health. We are hoping to open a detox program in the coming months, which is something that we've heard from a lot of our community members is in need, and we are really excited to help fulfill that," said Chisholm.

text:

En condiciones espantosas, un n√∫mero extraordinario de periodistas han muerto en el esfuerzo por contar la historia de los palestinos y los trabajadores humanitarios en Gaza ", detall√≥ la organizaci√≥n este lunes durante la retransmisi√≥n virtual de estos galardones.
